data.title: MediaLibrary
data.body:
With implementation for Windows Phone, iOS and Windows 8

Implemented position get/set for iOS.

It also seemed to me that the iOS build was broken because the `internal delegate void FinishedPlayingHandler(object sender, EventArgs args);` wasn't definied on iOS, but was used in the Song.IOS.cs, so I added it for iOS too.

data.title: Fixed texture memory leak when reloading textures after app resume on Android
data.body:
If I suspend and resume my app 4 times, then Android OS kills it for using too much memory.
To fix the leak I call `GL.DeleteTextures(1, ref glTexture)` inside `Texture.PlatformGraphicsDeviceResetting()`.

data.title: Better detection of graphics mode on Android.
data.body:
This fixes crash when resuming app after sleep on HTC One X (EglException: MakeCurrent failed with error 12297).
Related bugreport: [More App Resume Issues - Latest MG Build Crashes Device](http://community.monogame.net/t/more-app-resume-issues-latest-mg-build-crashes-device/491)

data.title: [BUG] [Windows] Seems like I should post this here.
data.body:
Managed Debugging Assistant 'ContextSwitchDeadlock' has detected a problem in 'D:\Projects\GitHub\Rhetris\bin\WindowsGL\Debug\Rhetris.vshost.exe'.

Additional Information: The CLR has been unable to transition from COM context 0x4beea8 to COM context 0x4bf018 for 60 seconds. The thread that owns the destination context/apartment is most likely either doing a non pumping wait or processing a very long running operation without pumping Windows messages. This situation generally has a negative performance impact and may even lead to the application becoming non responsive or memory usage accumulating continually over time. To avoid this problem, all single threaded apartment (STA) threads should use pumping wait primitives (such as CoWaitForMultipleHandles) and routinely pump messages during long running operations.

If there is a handler for this exception, the program may be safely continued.

Full zipped dump here(67MB): http://www.mediafire.com/download/m9p8fz20d1gpzxg/Rhetris.vshost_Monogame.zip

data.title: More IntermediateSerializer
data.body:
This is a follow up to https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2621.

With this PR i've been able to do some limited deserialization using `IntermediateSerializer`.

In the process of getting this working I've noticed that the design of the `IntermediateSerializer` is very much like that of the `ContentTypeReader`/`ContentTypeWriter` system.  I'm using the setup of that system as additional help to the blog posts and MSDN docs.

We currently only support float, int, and string fields/properties, but now that I have the system basically working it is easy to add serializers for a bunch of additional types.

No support for deserialization of collections/dictionaries/arrays/lists yet.

No serialization (writing) support yet, that will most likely be last.

Note i'm being careful to be thread safe with the design here, so we can enable parallel processing of content in the upcoming weeks.

data.title: Arrows keys being detected as Keys.LeftShift
data.body:
When using any of the left/right/up.down arrow keys, KeyState.IsKeyDown() correctly reports that particular key being depressed. However, KeyState.IsKeyDown() also reports Keys.LeftShift being depressed when any one of these keys is depressed.

I have noticed this bug on my Acer V5-572P-6858 laptop running Windows 7 Pro 64-bit. This issue was not present on another (desktop) computer running the same version of Windows and which has a wireless Logitech Cordless Internet Pro keyboard (Model Name: Y-RAJ56A).

This might be related to these previous issues that I found.

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2055

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1873

data.title: Fix GetData for Texture3D.Directx
data.body: This fix is similar to #2622, but I haven't added support for elementCount and I haven't tested it.

data.title: Fixed Texture2D.GetData on DirectX platforms
data.body:
Fixes #2348
Added support for the element count parameter
Added option to read the stream quickly if row pitch matches row size.

The previous implementation was wrong because the output type was mistaken for the input type and the incorrect size was used when reading (1 for byte vs 4 for color).

data.title: IntermediateSerializer Skeleton
data.body:
This PR adds the initial skeleton of the various IntermediateSerializer classes as described from the XNA docs.  The implementation does not work yet.

I'm also starting to port over the work @JamesLupiani  did in the XmlImporter (see https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2380) which basically implements what the IntermediateSerializer classes need to do.

Eventually we should be able to replace the current `XmlImporter` implementation with a single call to `IntermediateSerializer.Deserialize()`.  This is in fact how i'm testing that this works.

My next step is to implement the overloaded `ContentTypeSerializer` which is what seems to drive the entire XML serialization process.  This looks like a very similar design to how the `ContentTypeWriter`/`ContentTypeReader` system works.

data.title: Music doesn't play correctly on Windows 7 (DirectX)
data.body:
Hi, When I go to play an wma/xnb song WITHOUT the Visual Studio debugger attached, the first time I play a song, it does not play. Upon subsequent attempts to play ANY song within the same run of the game, I briefly hear the FIRST song play before it fades away (I have some code that fades out one song before fading in another).

If I run the game through the debugger, I get the exception listed below the first time I try to call MediaPlayer.Play(media);. If I then continue exeuction, the song will play normally.The exception will not be thrown after that. However, any subsequent attempts to play songs always play the first song that was played, rather than the correct one.

Additionally, something is weird about this exception, as I put a try/catch block around MediaPlayer.Play, but it does not catch the exception, so I can't report the exact call stack from this exception.

BTW, what is the underlying tech behind playing music? OpenAL, something from Microsoft?

A first chance exception of type 'SharpDX.SharpDXException' occurred in SharpDX.dll

Additional information: HRESULT: [0x80004002], Module: [General], ApiCode: [E_NOINTERFACE/No such interface supported], Message: No such interface supported

data.title: Can't access desktop resolution
data.body:
In XNA, I was able to use GraphicsAdapter.DefaultAdapter.CurrentDisplayMode.Width and Height to access the desktop resolution. In Monogame, it always returns 800x600.

This is important for me, as my game defaults to the desktop resolution the first time that you launch it.

data.title: Get android working again
data.body:
Get platforms that return false in BeforeRun working again (Just Android)

I broke this before, the Stopwatch would never be created.

refs #2615

data.title: ReflectiveWriter
data.body: First attempt at implementing support for the content pipeline `ReflectiveWriter` using the runtime `ReflectiveReader` as a guide.  Seems to work correctly with my simple test cases, but it possibly still has issues with it.

data.title: Crash on start on android
data.body:
It's a bug I introduced :(

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/9a6d75d6e5aae8fbef92aaddd6f53c8a954571e7#commitcomment-6439650
Found by @mhughson, thanks!

Looking at this, it looks like we have 3 ways to set up the run loop:

Use the switch on runBehavior in Game.Run. runBehavior comes from Platform.DefaultRunBehavior (So it is Async or Sync depending on what the platform supports). This is the normal way.

Boot up the run loop yourself in Platform.BeforeRun and return false. (Only Android does this)

I think we could (and should) change android over to use the normal way of doing this, it'll make the Game run loop code have one less hack.

Currently on Android Game.BeforeRun is never called due to this custom behaviour. Android also has to manually keep track of if Game has been initialized to call DoInitialize.

One change I am planning to do as part of this is to change GamePlatform.BeforeRun to be void rather than returning bool. I don't see any platform other than Android that returns false here, so AFAIK this should be okay.

To hack-fix this on your local copy, copy `_gameTimer = Stopwatch.StartNew();` up to the start of Platform.Run(GameRunBehavior) like:

``` c#
if (!Platform.BeforeRun())
{
    _gameTimer = Stopwatch.StartNew();
    return;
}
```

data.title: Fixed Game.Exit() crash on WinGL and Linux platforms.
data.body:
We must not call Game.Tick() after Game.Exit().
Fixes issue #2605.

data.title: Issue2612 bugfix
data.body:
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2612

Looks like it fix crashes after restart (deacitvation/activation) on windows phone.

data.body:
I'm running Linux Mint 16, mono version 3.2.1 and monodevelop 5.1.
After git clone, I ran mono Protobuild.exe, and there were no errors.
But when I open the MonoGame.Framework.Linux solution, there are several missing references, which have the error Assembly not found for framework  Mono / .NET 4.0:
OpenTK
AssimpNet
ManagedPVRTC
NAudio
NVidia.TextureTools
SharpFont

Is this to be expected, that I have to figure out where to get all of these and install them also, or am I missing something?

Thanks,
Bruce

data.title: Redo the IsRunningSlowly calculation
data.body:
Our previous method for calculating if we were running slowly was to time a whole frame (including Present time). If this is >= TargetElapsedTime then we decided we were running slowly.
Unfortunately this can be basically all of the time as Present waits for vsync (hardware/driver dependent).

I've made a test project to see how IsRunningSlowly behaves in XNA. It seems that when the game does many Update calls before a Draw call this triggers IsRunningSlowly to become true.
It only becomes unset after a few times of just doing a single Update per Draw call.

I've implemented this in MonoGame, the results don't exactly match XNA, but they are very close. We only set IsRunningSlowly at the same times as them, we unset it a bit sooner however.

The 5 used for triggering IsRunningSlowly I arbitrarily chose.

Fixes #2595 (Contains good discussion on the issue)

data.title: Fix burst of Game.Update calls at the start of the game
data.body:
Found while investigating #2595
Test project: https://github.com/danzel/DrawTextTest/tree/isrunningslowlytest

We start the Game._gameTimer Stopwatch when the Game class is constructed. This is before we have done any of the system initialisation, which can take a while.
As such, the first time we get in to Tick, we think the game has already been running for quite a while and we need to do lots of Update calls to catch up (usually _maxElapsedTime  worth).

Instead now we only start the StopWatch when we are about to start the Update/Draw loop.

With the above test project on XNA start up looks like (see out.txt):

```
Update 0 False, 
Update 1 False, 
Draw 0 False, 
Update 2 False, 
Update 3 False, 
Draw 1 False, 
Update 4 False, 
Draw 2 False, 
Update 5 False, 
(And so on, Update Draw...)
```

But in Monogame it looked like:

```
Update 0 True, 
Update 1 True, 
Update 2 True, 
Update 3 True, 
Update 4 True, 
Update 5 True, 
Update 6 True, 
Update 7 True, 
Update 8 True, 
Update 9 True, 
Update 10 True, 
Update 11 True, 
Update 12 True, 
Update 13 True, 
Update 14 True, 
Draw 0 True, 
Update 15 True, 
Update 16 True, 
Update 17 True, 
Draw 1 True, 
Update 18 False, 
Draw 2 False, 
Update 19 False, 
Draw 3 False, 
(And so on)
```

Now the start of monogame looks like:

```
Update 0 False, 
Draw 0 False, 
Update 1 False, 
Update 2 False, 
Draw 1 False, 
Update 3 False, 
Draw 2 False, 
Update 4 False, 
Draw 3 False, 
(silky smooth!)
```

data.title: Win GL - Invalid operation upon game exiting
data.body:
See https://github.com/Cocos2DXNA/MonoGame/commit/5bed01aecab37aec64553971a7f7998efdd950df

We have to check if the window is visible before trying to get the mouse state. When the window is not visible but update() queries the mouse state, an InvalidOperationException is raised.

data.title: SpriteFont Optimizations Pt. 1
data.body:
This is a first pass at SpriteFont optimization.

My measurements currently show that when rendering a few larger strings MonoGame w/ DirectX 11 is slightly faster than XNA w/ DirectX 9.

This PR improves the performance of MonoGame font rendering by a small amount on the PC.  It is mostly from adding a custom IEqualityComparer for `char` instead of relying on the `GenericEqualityComparer` used by default.  This might prove to be a bigger win under Mono on non-Windows platforms.

While I was at this I did a few small cleanups, but kept them to a minimum.

data.title: Do not generate any networking projects for Angle.
data.body:
Angle is just for testing GLES and does not need networking.

Fixes #2592

data.title: Vertex Texture Fetch Not Supported
data.body: Vertex Texture Fetch is not currently supported by Monogame. It would be great to have support for it. High-priority platforms for me are Windows (DirectX) and PS4.

Includes
- New .Net package
- Added Android/iOS/MacOS experimental project templates to main MG NuGet
- Added build specific builds to binaries package (Win 8 x86/x64/ARM/Any) (WinGL x86/x64/Any)

Published as of commit https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/e58c2cef02226c08bb3a132fb90282061914ce29

data.title: Implement Android Fast App Resume [$1100 bounty]
data.body:
The latest version of Xamarin Android includes the needed support to let games keep their OpenGL context when paused. This would allow Monogame based games to resume much faster after a user leaves and then comes back into the game.

The relevant thread is here:
http://forums.xamarin.com/discussion/621/androidgameview-pause-without-losing-gl-context/p2

It looks as if this needs a change on the Monogame side in order to be enabled. Does anyone have a patch already in progress?
